title: Basic Consonants
objectives: Understand how to pronounce ㄱ ㄴ ㄷ ㄹ ㅁ ㅂ
Recognize these consonants in syllable blocks
context: Korean uses an alphabet called Hangul (한글), created in 1443. Unlike Chinese characters, Hangul is phonetic - each letter represents a sound.
Consonants and vowels combine into syllable blocks. Each block represents one syllable. For example: 가 = ㄱ + ㅏ (g + a = ga).
Let's start with the first 6 consonants. These are the most common and easiest to learn!
explanation: ㄱ sounds like 'g' at the start of a word (like 'go'), but like 'k' at the end (like 'book').
ㄴ is always pronounced like 'n' in 'no'. Very consistent!
ㄷ sounds like 'd' at the start (like 'dog'), but like 't' at the end (like 'cat').
ㄹ is tricky! It's between 'r' and 'l'. At the start it's more like 'r', in the middle/end more like 'l'.
ㅁ is always 'm' like in 'mom'. Easy!
ㅂ sounds like 'b' at the start (like 'ball'), but like 'p' at the end (like 'cup').
Notice: Korean consonants can sound different depending on where they are in a word. This is normal!
Practice tip: Say each consonant + 'ah' sound (아) to practice: 가, 나, 다, 라, 마, 바

title: More Consonants
objectives: Understand the pronunciation of ㅅ ㅇ ㅈ ㅎ
context: You've learned your first 6 consonants! Now let's add 4 more common consonants.
These include ㅇ which is special - it's silent at the start of syllables but pronounced 'ng' at the end.
With these 10 consonants, you'll be able to read many Korean words!

sentences.english: a (like in 'ah') - ㅇ is silent here

explanation: ㅅ is pronounced like 's' in 'see'. At the end of syllables, it's still 's' or sometimes 't' sound.
ㅇ is the most unique! At the start of a syllable, it's completely silent (아 = 'a'). At the end, it's the 'ng' sound (강 = 'gang').
ㅈ sounds like 'j' in 'jump'. It's between an English 'j' and 'ch' sound.
ㅎ is like 'h' in 'hello'. Simple and consistent!
Try reading: 하나 (hana = one), 사과 (sagwa = apple), 자다 (jada = to sleep)
Remember: ㅇ at the start is silent, ㅇ at the end is 'ng'!

title: Basic Vowels
objectives: Understand how vowels combine with consonants
context: Now that you know consonants, let's learn vowels! Korean has 21 vowels total, but we'll start with the 6 most basic ones.
Korean vowels are designed based on three elements: sky (·), earth (ㅡ), and human (ㅣ). This philosophy makes them easier to remember!
Once you know these 6 vowels + the 10 consonants you learned, you can make over 60 different syllables!
explanation: ㅏ sounds like 'a' in 'father'. It's written vertically on the right of consonants: 가, 나, 다
ㅓ sounds like 'uh' or 'o' in 'love'. Also written vertically: 거, 너, 더
ㅗ sounds like 'o' in 'go'. Written horizontally below consonants: 고, 노, 도
ㅜ sounds like 'oo' in 'food'. Also horizontal: 구, 누, 두
ㅡ sounds like 'eu' - try saying 'uh' with your mouth more closed. Horizontal: 그, 느, 드
ㅣ sounds like 'ee' in 'bee'. Vertical on the right: 기, 니, 디
Vowel position rule: Vertical vowels (ㅏㅓㅣ) go on the RIGHT. Horizontal vowels (ㅗㅜㅡ) go BELOW.
Practice: Try writing and reading 가거고구그기 (ga-geo-go-gu-geu-gi)!

title: Complex Vowels
objectives: Practice reading syllables with complex vowels
context: Korean has 10 basic vowels and 11 complex vowels. Complex vowels are made by combining two basic vowels together!
For example: ㅏ + ㅣ = ㅐ (like 'ae' in 'cat'). These compound vowels follow logical patterns.
Learning these will help you read and pronounce Korean words more accurately.
explanation: ㅐ (ae) and ㅔ (e) sound almost identical in modern Korean - like 'eh' in 'bed'. Many Koreans pronounce them the same!
ㅚ is supposed to sound like 'we' but most Koreans pronounce it like ㅞ or just 'we/oe'.
ㅟ sounds like 'wee' in 'sweet'. It's ㅜ + ㅣ combined.
ㅢ is tricky! It sounds like 'ui' (oo-ee blended) but only at the start of words. Otherwise it often sounds like 'i'.
ㅑ (ya) is like 'ya' in 'yard'. It's the 'y' version of ㅏ.
ㅕ (yeo) is like 'yo' in 'yogurt'. It's the 'y' version of ㅓ.
Pattern: Adding a short line (ㅣ) to basic vowels makes them 'y' sounds: ㅏ→ㅑ, ㅓ→ㅕ, ㅗ→ㅛ, ㅜ→ㅠ

title: Essential Greetings
objectives: Understand when to use each greeting
context: Congratulations on learning Hangul! Now let's put it to use with real Korean phrases.
Korean culture values politeness, so greetings are very important. The phrases you'll learn here work in most situations.
Notice that many greetings end with 요 (yo) - this makes them polite!

sentences.english: Thank you. Goodbye (to the person leaving).

explanation: 안녕하세요 (annyeonghaseyo) literally means 'Are you at peace?' It's used for hello/hi in polite situations.
There are TWO goodbyes in Korean! 안녕히 가세요 = 'go peacefully' (say to someone leaving). 안녕히 계세요 = 'stay peacefully' (say when you're leaving).
감사합니다 (gamsahamnida) is formal 'thank you'. You can also say 고맙습니다 (gomapseumnida) which is slightly less formal.
죄송합니다 (joesonghamnida) is formal apology. For casual 'sorry' you can say 미안해요 (mianhaeyo).
네 (ne) means yes. Sometimes Koreans say 예 (ye) which is more formal.
아니요 (aniyo) means no. In casual speech, you might hear 아니 (ani).
Pro tip: When answering the phone, Koreans say 여보세요 (yeoboseyo) = hello!

title: Self Introduction
objectives: Learn how to introduce yourself in Korean
Practice saying your name and nationality
Use basic sentence structures for self-introduction
context: In Korean culture, proper introductions are important! You'll often introduce yourself by name, then add information about where you're from.
The word order is different from English: 'I + name + am' becomes '저는 [name]이에요/예요' (jeoneun [name]ieyo/yeyo).
Let's learn the essentials for introducing yourself in any situation!
explanation: 저 (jeo) is the polite form of 'I/me'. In casual speech, you'd use 나 (na), but 저 is safer for introductions.
는 (neun) is a topic particle that follows nouns. 저는 (jeoneun) means 'As for me...' or simply 'I'.
이에요 vs 예요: Use 이에요 after words ending in consonants (데이비드이에요), use 예요 after vowels (사라예요).
입니다 (imnida) is more formal than 이에요/예요. Use it in professional settings or formal situations.
제 (je) is possessive 'my'. It's 저 + 의 combined. So 제 이름 = 'my name'.
Countries: 미국 (America), 한국 (Korea), 중국 (China), 일본 (Japan), 영국 (England).
Add 사람 (saram = person) after country names to say nationality: 미국 사람 = American person.

title: Friendly Checks & Small Talk
objectives: Ask and answer 'How are you?' naturally
Use polite phrases for everyday encounters
Respond to casual small talk with confidence
context: After greeting someone, Koreans often check in with a quick small-talk question.
Polite endings like 요 keep things friendly without being too formal.
These phrases help you connect quickly without needing long sentences.

vocabulary.english: Please take care of me / Let's work well together

sentences.english: Yes, I'm good. Long time no see!
Nice to meet you. Please take care of me.
Good morning. Have a good day.

explanation: 잘 지내요? is the standard 'How are you?' for casual-polite settings. Answer with 네, 잘 지내요 or so-so: 그럭저럭이에요.
오랜만이에요 literally means 'It's been a long time.' Great for meeting someone after a while.
처음 뵙겠습니다 is business-level polite. Follow it with 잘 부탁드립니다 when starting a relationship or project.
좋은 아침이에요 is used less often than in English, but it's understood. Koreans often just say 안녕하세요 in the morning too.
좋은 하루 보내세요 is a warm send-off. You can also say 좋은 밤 되세요 (Have a good night).

title: Getting Attention & Simple Requests
objectives: Ask for simple help or items
context: These phrases are lifesavers when you need help or clarification.
They are short, polite, and work in almost any everyday situation.
Focus on tone: keep your voice gentle and end with 요 to stay polite.

sentences.english: Excuse me, is this seat taken?
One moment. Please wait just a bit.
Please give me this. I'll pay by card.

sentences.korean: 천천히 말해 주세요. 이해 못 했어요.
sentences.english: Please speak slowly. I didn't understand.
sentences.romanization: cheoncheonhi malhae juseyo. ihae mot haesseoyo.

sentences.english: Are you okay? Can I help you?

explanation: 저기요 gets attention politely, like saying 'excuse me' to a waiter. 실례합니다 is stronger/apologetic (e.g., squeezing by someone).
주세요 is the magic polite request ending. Attach it after nouns (이거 주세요 = this please) or verb stems (도와주세요 = help me please).
천천히 말해 주세요 + 다시 말해 주세요 are key for learners. Don't be shy to use them—they're common and appreciated.
못 했어요 means 'couldn't do it/didn't manage.' 이해 못 했어요 = I didn't (couldn't) understand.
괜찮아요 works both ways: as a question ('Are you okay?') and as a response ('It's fine/I'm okay').

title: Verb Basics & Present Tense
context: Korean verbs are the engine of sentences. You need only the verb to make a full idea!
Dictionary forms end with -다. To speak politely, you change that ending to -아요/어요/해요.
Most verbs follow simple patterns once you know the final vowel.

sentences.english: I drink water. I drink coffee too.

explanation: Drop 다 and add -아요 after bright vowels (ㅏ/ㅗ): 가다 → 가요, 보다 → 봐요. Add -어요 after other vowels: 먹다 → 먹어요, 마시다 → 마셔요.
하다 verbs always become 해요: 하다 → 해요 (운동해요, 공부해요, 일해요).
은/는 marks topics, 이/가 marks subjects. You can often omit them in casual speech when context is clear.
Present tense in Korean covers present and near future, like 'I go/I will go' depending on context.
Stress syllables smoothly. No strong stress like English; keep rhythm even.

title: Daily Routine Verbs
context: A few core verbs cover most of your day: waking, working, studying, meeting, relaxing.
Add time words like 아침에 (in the morning) or 지금 (now) to give simple structure.
Object particles 을/를 attach to the thing you act on, but they often drop in speech.

sentences.english: I wake up in the morning and wash my face.
I work at the office. At lunch I meet a coworker.
In the evening I work out and rest.
I study Korean on the weekend.
I go to sleep around midnight.

explanation: Object particles: 을 after consonant (한국어를), 를 after vowel (커피를). They can drop if the meaning is clear: 한국어 공부해요.
-아서/어서 links actions in sequence with cause/flow: 일어나서 씻어요 = I wake up and wash (right after).
Company/workplace phrases often use 에서 to show where an action happens: 회사에서 일해요, 집에서 쉬어요.
Time markers: 아침에 (in the morning), 점심에 (at lunchtime), 저녁에 (in the evening), 밤에 (at night).
For routines, present tense alone implies habit: 주말에 운동해요 = I work out on weekends.

title: Questions, Likes, and Negatives
objectives: Say you don't do something using 안/못
context: Two small words open up conversation: 좋아하다 (to like) and -고 싶다 (to want).
안 and 못 sit before verbs to make simple negatives. 안 = don't, 못 = can't (unable).
Rising intonation turns statements into questions, or add -아요/어요? with a question mark.

vocabulary.english: Is it okay? / Are you okay?

sentences.english: I can't go today. Tomorrow works.
Do you need it? No, it's okay.

explanation: Add -아요/어요? with rising tone to ask yes/no questions. WH-words (뭐/언제/어디/누구/왜/어떻게) stay in place: 누구 좋아해요?
좋아하다 takes an object: 커피를 좋아해요. 'I like coffee.'
-고 싶어요 attaches to verb stems to express desire: 가고 싶어요 (I want to go), 배우고 싶어요 (I want to learn).
안 + verb = don't/won't (choice). 못 + verb = can't (ability/circumstance).
필요하다 means 'to need.' You can say 필요 없어요 = I don't need it.

title: People & Relationships
objectives: Combine topics with 은/는 and subjects with 이/가
context: Talking about family, friends, and coworkers is everyday conversation.
Possessive 제/제 친구 adds warmth and clarity when introducing people.
Particles help mark who we're talking about and who is acting.
explanation: 제 is the polite 'my' (from 저 + 의). Use 내 for casual. 제 친구, 제 부모님 are safer than 내 with new people.
당신 is rarely used in conversation except between spouses or in customer service. Use 이름+씨 (e.g., 민수 씨) to say 'you.'
은/는 sets the topic (제 친구는...), 이/가 marks the subject (동료가...). Both can appear in one sentence if needed.
For respect toward elders/parents, use honorific verbs like 계시다 (to be/exist honorifically) instead of 있다: 부모님이 계세요.
To introduce someone: 이쪽은 제 친구 민수예요 = This is my friend Minsu.

title: Places & Location Particles
context: 에 marks location or destination; 에서 marks where an action happens.
Knowing a few building words helps with errands and commuting.
Attach place + 에/에서 before the verb—no prepositions needed.

sentences.english: I'm going to the office now.
On weekends I exercise at the park.
The bank is next to the market.
There are many books at the library.

explanation: 에 answers 'to/at/in' for states or destinations: 집에 있어요 (at home), 학교에 가요 (go to school).
에서 answers 'at/in' for actions: 집에서 공부해요 (study at home), 회사에서 일해요 (work at the office).
With movement verbs 가다/오다, use 에: 집에 가요. With action verbs like 일하다/공부하다, use 에서.
Position words pair with 에: 학교 옆에 (next to), 시장 안에 (inside), 공원 근처에 (near the park).
Order: [Place + particle] + [time word] + verb is flexible. Common flow: 오늘 학교에서 수업해요 (Today at school I have class).

title: There Is / There Isn't
objectives: Use 있다/없다 for existence and possession
Describe where things are with location words
context: 있다/없다 covers 'to have,' 'to be located,' and 'to exist.'
Combine with location markers to place objects and people.
These patterns appear everywhere: shops, directions, home descriptions.

vocabulary.english: to not exist / to not have

sentences.english: The cafe is in front of the station.
The bus stop is over there.
There is a cat at home.

explanation: 있다/없다 conjugate to 있어요/없어요 in polite present. With subjects, use 이/가: 화장실이 있어요? 아니요, 없어요.
For possession, Korean literally says 'Something exists (for me)': 저한테 시간 있어요 = I have time. 지갑이 없어요 = I don't have my wallet.
Location structure: [Place/Thing] + 이/가 + [Location word] + 에 있어요. Example: 은행이 시장 옆에 있어요.
여기/거기/저기 can replace a full place name when pointing. Add 에 to mark location: 거기에 있어요 = It's there.
없다 can sound abrupt alone; soften with 죄송하지만 or 미안해요 when refusing politely.

title: Korean Food Words & Flavors
objectives: Name staple Korean foods and drinks
Talk about taste with key adjectives
context: Food is central in Korean culture—knowing dishes helps you order confidently.
Describing flavors with simple adjectives goes a long way.
You can mix food nouns with 맛있어요/없어요 and other adjectives to react naturally.

sentences.english: Ramen is a bit spicy but tasty.
This soup is a little bland.

explanation: 맛있어요 = It's tasty. 맛없어요 = It's not tasty. Add 정말/진짜/너무 to intensify: 정말 맛있어요!
맵다 (to be spicy) conjugates to 매워요. Many Korean dishes are 맵고 짜요 (spicy and salty) but balanced.
밥 can mean 'rice' or 'meal.' 밥 먹었어요? often means 'Have you eaten? / How are you?'.
Use 조금 (a little) or 아주/정말 (very) before adjectives: 조금 매워요, 아주 맛있어요.
Add 은/는 to highlight contrast: 불고기는 안 매워요, 하지만 김치는 매워요.

title: Ordering Food Like a Local
objectives: Point and choose items with 이거/저거
context: Korean restaurants often use direct but polite phrases with 주세요.
Pointing with 이거 (this) and using numbers + 개 makes ordering simple even without reading the menu.
Takeout, dine-in, and payment each have short standard lines.

sentences.english: This one (1) and that one (2), please.
Bill, please. I'll pay by card.

explanation: Point + number + counter + 주세요 is the core ordering pattern: 이거 두 개 주세요 (Please give me two of these).
Native numbers 1-4 often shorten before counters: 하나→한, 둘→두, 셋→세, 넷→네: 불고기 두 개 주세요.
For dine-in vs takeout, staff may ask '드시고 가세요?' Reply: 네, 먹고 갈게요 (eat here) / 포장해 주세요 (to go).
카드로요? 현금으로요? means 'By card? By cash?' Reply with the method you prefer.
After paying, you'll often hear 수고하세요 (take care/thanks for your effort) as you leave.

title: Dietary Needs & Restaurant Etiquette
objectives: Ask for less spice, less salt, or substitutions
Use polite apologies and thanks in restaurants
context: Staff appreciate clear, polite requests about spice level or allergies.
Korean dishes are often shared; learn how to speak up kindly.
Short set phrases handle most needs without long grammar.

sentences.english: Do you have something not spicy?
Please make it a little less spicy.
I'm vegetarian. Please leave out the meat.
Thank you. Enjoy your meal (response to staff).

explanation: 덜/더 + adjective turns into 'less/more': 덜 맵게, 더 맵게. Add 조금 for extra softness: 조금 덜 맵게 해 주세요.
짠 음식 is salty food. Say 짜지 않게 해 주세요 = Please make it not too salty.
For allergies, be direct: 저는 땅콩 알레르기가 있어요 (I have a peanut allergy). Follow with 못 먹어요 (I can't eat it).
채식주의자예요 (I'm vegetarian) / 비건이에요 (I'm vegan). Ask '고기 들어가요?' = Does this have meat?
맛있게 드세요 is a polite 'enjoy' used by staff or to others. You respond with 잘 먹겠습니다 before eating in formal settings.

title: Adjective Basics
context: Korean 'adjectives' are actually descriptive verbs ending in -다.
They conjugate just like action verbs to make polite statements.
A few versatile adjectives cover taste, price, size, and looks.

sentences.english: The room is a bit small.

explanation: Drop 다, add -아요/어요: 비싸다 → 비싸요, 싸다 → 싸요, 괜찮다 → 괜찮아요.
ㅂ irregular not here yet; these are regular. Notice 예쁘다 → 예뻐요 (merge ㅡ to ㅓ).
Add 조금/좀 to soften: 좀 비싸요 (a bit pricey). Add 아주/정말 to strengthen: 정말 예뻐요.
괜찮아요 means 'It's fine/I'm fine' and is a polite neutral response in many contexts.
Adjectives can stand as sentences: 맛있어요! (It's delicious!), 따뜻해요 (It's warm).

title: Describing People & Things
objectives: Use adjectives for mood, condition, and personality
Softly agree or disagree with descriptions
context: Korean often puts adjectives directly before nouns using a short modifier form.
Describing how people feel or act helps with daily check-ins.
Use intensifiers like 정말/좀 to fine-tune your tone.

sentences.english: The weather is cool and nice.

explanation: Adjectives before nouns use -은/-ㄴ after dropping 다: 친절하다 → 친절한 사람, 따뜻하다 → 따뜻한 커피. With ㅂ irregulars (e.g., 따뜻하다 regular), other irregular rules apply later.
Add 너무/정말 for stronger tone: 너무 바빠요 (I'm very busy). Add 조금/좀 to soften complaints: 좀 피곤해요.
하다 adjectives like 건강하다 behave like verbs but still describe state: 저는 건강해요.
When agreeing politely: 맞아요/네, 그래요. When soft disagreeing: 그런 것 같아요 (I think it's like that), 조금 다른 것 같아요 (I think it's a bit different).
재미있다 is often pronounced 재미있다/재밌다 (both common). Both conjugate to 재미있어요/재밌어요.

title: Comparisons & Degree
objectives: Compare things using 더/덜 and 제일
Soften or strengthen adjectives with adverbs
context: Comparatives in Korean are simple—no verb changes, just add 더 (more) or 덜 (less).
Use 제일/가장 for 'the most' and 조금/정말/너무 to dial intensity.
Adding 것 같아요 expresses a thoughtful opinion rather than a blunt fact.

sentences.english: I think I'm a little tired.
I think this one is better.

explanation: 더/덜 go before the adjective: 더 커요 (bigger), 덜 매워요 (less spicy). No need for 'than' word; context or a phrase like X보다 clarifies: 서울보다 부산이 덜 비싸요.
제일/가장 before adjectives mark the superlative: 제일 맛있어요 = It's the most delicious.
너무 can mean 'too' or 'very' depending on tone. For positive emphasis without 'too,' use 정말/진짜.
것 같아요 softens statements into opinions: 따뜻한 것 같아요 (It seems warm). You can add '제 생각에는' = In my opinion.
Combine: 저는 덜 짠 음식이 제일 좋아요 = I like less salty food the most.

title: Days & Time Words
objectives: Name days and simple time markers
Place time expressions naturally in sentences
context: Knowing when something happens is often more important than the full sentence.
Korean time words go before the verb and often before particles like 에 (at).
Combine with present tense to talk about plans, routines, and recent past.

sentences.english: I have a meeting tomorrow morning.

explanation: Time words usually come early: [Time] + [Place] + [Verb]. Example: 내일 회사에서 일해요 (Tomorrow I work at the office).
아침/점심/저녁 can pair with 에 to mean 'in/at': 아침에, 점심에, 저녁에.
언제 is flexible: 언제 만나요? 언제 출발해요?
주말 (weekend) vs 주중 (during the week). Add 이번/다음/지난 before weeks or months: 이번 주, 다음 주.
곧 (soon) and 지금 (now) don't take 에. They act like adverbs right before the verb.

title: Clock Time & Appointments
objectives: Tell time with hours and minutes
context: Hours use native numbers (한 시, 두 시), minutes use Sino numbers (십 분, 삼십 분).
에 marks specific clock times: 세 시에 만나요 (Let's meet at 3).
약속 (appointment) and 시간 (time) show up constantly when scheduling.
explanation: Hours use native numbers: 한/두/세/네/다섯/여섯/일곱/여덟/아홉/열 시. Minutes use Sino numbers: 십 분 (10), 이십 분 (20), 삼십 분 (30).
반 = half past: 두 시 반 (2:30). For quarter past, say 십오 분 (15 minutes).
Use -에 for specific times: 오전 아홉 시에 (at 9 a.m.). For 'around,' add 쯤: 여섯 시쯤에.
시간 있어요? = Do you have time? 없어요 = I don't. 조금 있어요 = I have a little.
예약하다 combines 예약 (reservation) + 하다. You can 예약했어요 (I reserved) or 예약하고 싶어요 (I want to book).

title: Making Plans & Future Tense
context: Future tense is simple: verb stem + -(으)ㄹ 거예요 handles intentions and predictions.
Korean invitations often use 같이 (together) and -ㄹ래요?/갈래요? to propose gently.
Polite checking phrases keep scheduling smooth.

sentences.english: Do you want to have lunch together tomorrow?
I'm going to work out in the evening.
I think I won't have time on the weekend.
I'll check my schedule and let you know.

sentences.korean: 그날은 조금 어려워요. 다른 날 가능해요?
sentences.english: That day is a bit difficult. Is another day possible?
sentences.romanization: geunareun jogeum eoryeowoyo. dareun nal ganeunghaeyo?

explanation: -(으)ㄹ 거예요 adds a future/intent meaning. Add -을 after consonants, -ㄹ after vowels: 가다 → 갈 거예요, 먹다 → 먹을 거예요.
-ㄹ래요? suggests plans softly: 커피 마실래요? 같이 갈래요? It's more casual than -(으)실래요? but polite enough with 요.
가능해요 = It's possible. 어려워요 = It's hard/difficult. Combine with 조금 to soften refusals.
일정 확인하고 알려줄게요 literally 'I'll check the schedule and will let you know.' -줄게요 is a friendly promise.
Use 것 같아요 to hedge: 아마 늦을 것 같아요 (I think I'll be late).

title: Transportation Essentials
context: Public transit in Korea is extensive—knowing the key words keeps you moving.
타다 (to ride) and 내리다 (to get off) pair with any vehicle.
Cards are king: a 교통카드 works on buses, subways, and some taxis.

sentences.english: I take the bus to the office.
I got off two stops earlier.
At Gangnam Station I transfer to Line 2.
Do you have a transit card? Did you top it up?

explanation: Vehicles take object particle sometimes but often omitted: 버스(를) 타요. Use 에서 with stations for actions: 역에서 갈아타요.
호선 is subway line: 2호선 (line 2), 9호선 (line 9). Attach 으로/로 after the line number.
충전하다 = to recharge/top up (a card). 잔액 means remaining balance: 잔액이 없어요 (no balance).
Taxis often ask '카드요? 현금요?' Answer with the method. Some taxis accept 교통카드 taps too.
For buses, press the stop button before your stop: 다음 정류장에서 내릴게요 (I'll get off at the next stop).

title: Asking for Directions
context: Short, direct phrases are best when asking strangers for help.
Directional nouns pair with 으로/로 to indicate movement.
Landmark-based directions are more common than exact addresses.

sentences.english: At that crosswalk over there, go left.
Go straight two blocks and turn right.
The exit is on the opposite side.

explanation: Direction question frame: [Place] 어디에 있어요? Use 에 to mark static location. To ask how to get there, switch to 어떻게 가요?
-으로/로 after a direction shows route: 왼쪽으로 가세요 (go to the left), 직진하세요 (go straight).
Landmarks are key: 신호등/횡단보도/편의점/은행 + 에서/앞에서 give clear instructions.
맞은편 = across from. 건너편 also works. Use -에 to mark: 역 맞은편에 있어요 (It's across from the station).
In subway stations, 출구 numbers matter: 3번 출구로 나가세요 (exit through gate 3).

title: Travel Timing & Fixes
objectives: Ask how long a trip takes
Handle delays, traffic, and being lost
Confirm you're on the right route
context: Even with maps, you need quick phrases to confirm you're headed correctly.
Korean commuters talk about traffic (막히다) and duration (얼마나 걸려요?).
Stay polite but clear when asking to speed up or double-checking stops.

sentences.english: How long does it take from here to the airport?
The road is really jammed right now.

sentences.korean: 이 버스 강남역 가는 거 맞아요?
sentences.english: Does this bus go to Gangnam Station?
sentences.romanization: i beoseu gangnam-yeok ganeun geo majayo?

sentences.english: I have to get off at the next stop.
I'm lost. Where am I here?

explanation: 얼마나 걸려요? asks duration. Reply with minutes/hours: 20분 걸려요 (takes 20 minutes), 한 시간쯤 걸려요 (about an hour).
막히다 conjugates to 막혀요. 'Traffic is heavy' = 차가 많이 막혀요.
Check routes: [Transport] + [destination] + 가요/가는 거예요? e.g., 이 기차 부산 가요?
To request faster/slower politely: 조금만 빨리 가 주세요 / 천천히 가 주세요 (for taxis).
If lost, pair place words: 여기 근처에 은행 있어요? 길을 잃었어요, 도와주세요 (I'm lost, please help).

title: Sino-Korean Numbers
objectives: Count with 일 이 삼 사 오 and beyond
Use Sino numbers for dates, money, and minutes
context: Korean has two number systems. Sino-Korean numbers (한자어 수) come from Chinese and handle money, minutes, phone numbers, floors, months, and more.
Pattern is regular: 일(1) 이(2) 삼(3) 사(4) 오(5) 육(6) 칠(7) 팔(8) 구(9) 십(10).
Combine tens and hundreds like Lego blocks: 이십(20), 삼십오(35), 백오십(150).
explanation: Dates use Sino numbers for months and days: 3월 15일 (March 15th). Months are number + 월; days are number + 일.
Phone numbers often use 공 (0) instead of 영. Read digits individually: 010 → 공-일-공.
Money uses 원 with Sino numbers: 만 원 (10,000 won), 삼만 육천 원 (36,000 won).
Floors also Sino: 1층 (il cheung), 12층 (sibi cheung).

title: Native Numbers & Basic Counters
objectives: Order small quantities in real situations
context: Native numbers handle age (살), hours (시), and everyday counting up to about 99.
Counters follow the number to match the type of thing you're counting.
Numbers 1-4 often shorten before counters (한/두/세/네).

sentences.english: I ordered two bottles of beer.

explanation: Short forms before counters: 하나→한, 둘→두, 셋→세, 넷→네. Example: 두 개, 세 명, 네 시.
개 is the all-purpose counter for inanimate items. 명 is for people (분 is the honorific people counter).
Use native numbers for age with 살: 저는 스물다섯 살이에요 (I'm 25).
Up to 99 uses native numbers: 열하나 (11), 스물 (20), 서른 (30), 마흔 (40), 쉰 (50). Sino numbers take over for large counts.
Counters come right after numbers: 사탕 다섯 개, 학생 여섯 명.

title: Practical Counting: Money, Time, Age
objectives: Tell time and age with correct systems
context: Korean swaps between Sino and native numbers depending on what you're counting.
Money, dates, minutes use Sino numbers; hours and age use native (with some exceptions).
Practice mixing both systems in one sentence for real-life fluency.

sentences.english: The room is on the 7th floor.

explanation: 가격/돈 use Sino numbers + 원: 삼만 칠천 원 (37,000 won). Asking price: 얼마예요?
Clock time mixes systems: hours = native (한 시, 두 시), minutes = Sino (십 분, 이십오 분).
Age uses native numbers with 살: 스물다섯 살 (25). In very formal settings, Sino with 세 sometimes appears, but 살 covers most cases.
층 uses Sino: 1층 (il cheung), 7층 (chil cheung). 번 marks order/number: 몇 번 버스예요? (Which bus number is it?).
Duration 'for X hours/minutes' uses -동안 or just counters: 두 시간 동안 공부했어요 (studied for two hours), 10분만 기다려 주세요 (please wait only 10 minutes).

title: Airport & Immigration
objectives: Ask for help with boarding and baggage
context: Airports use predictable phrases about passports, tickets, and luggage.
Immigration officers often ask about purpose of visit and length of stay.
Keep answers short and polite—simple present/future tense works well.

sentences.english: Please show your passport and boarding pass.
What is the purpose of your trip?
I'm a transfer passenger. Where should I go?

explanation: 입국 심사에서 you'll hear '여행 목적이 뭐예요?' (purpose) and '체류 기간이 얼마예요?' (length of stay). Prepare short answers: 관광/출장 (business) / 가족 방문.
Checked bag = 수하물, carry-on = 기내 반입. 부치다 means to check luggage. 수하물 찾는 곳 = baggage claim.
환승 means transfer. If you have a layover, say 환승이에요 and ask for the gate: 게이트가 어디예요?
Security asks '액체 있어요?' (Any liquids?) or '노트북 꺼내 주세요' (Please take out your laptop).
Numbers for dates use Sino: 1주일 (one week), 3일 (three days), 2달 (two months using native counter 달).

title: Hotels & Stays
objectives: Book, check in, and check out smoothly
Request essentials like Wi‑Fi and extra items
context: Hotels and guesthouses use many English loanwords, but polite Korean earns quick help.
Short requests with 있어요?/주세요 cover most needs.
Be ready to explain issues with simple adjectives (안 나와요/고장 났어요).

sentences.english: I have a reservation. I'd like to check in.

sentences.korean: 샤워기가 안 나와요. 방을 바꿔 주세요.
sentences.english: The shower doesn't work. Please change the room.
sentences.romanization: syawogi-ga an nawayo. bangeul bakkwo juseyo.

explanation: 체크인/체크아웃 times are usually stated in English numbers. Ask '체크아웃이 몇 시예요?'
비밀번호 literally 'secret number.' Some places say 비번 for short.
안 나와요 works for water/electricity: 물이 안 나와요 (no water). For broken items, use 고장 났어요.
Extra items: 담요(=blanket) 좀 더 주세요, 베개(=pillow) 하나만 더 주세요.
To request cleaning: 객실 청소 해 주세요 / 오늘은 청소 안 해도 돼요 (No cleaning needed today).

title: Shopping & Payment
objectives: Ask about prices, sizes, and colors
Try on items and request discounts
Handle receipts, tax refunds, and bags
context: Markets and shops are friendly to short, clear Korean. Many staff reply in simple English, but Korean gets better service.
Size and fit words are often English loanwords—listen for 사이즈, 라지, 스몰.
Receipts and tax-free forms are common for tourists; know the key terms.

sentences.english: Do you have one size bigger?
Do you have another color besides black?
Is there a discount? Is tax-free possible?

explanation: 사이즈 uses English letter sizes: 스몰/미디엄/라지. Numbers for shoes are in mm (e.g., 250).
입어 봐도 돼요? uses the permission pattern -아/어도 돼요? meaning 'Is it okay if...?'
할인 (discount) pairs with 카드 할인, 멤버십 할인. If price feels high, ask 조금만 깎아 주세요 (Please lower it a little).
면세 (tax-free) often requires a passport. 영수증 주세요 = Please give me a receipt.
For bags at stores: 봉투 필요하세요? Reply 필요 없어요 (No need) or 하나 주세요 (One please).

title: Emergencies & Health
objectives: Get help quickly in urgent situations
Call or direct someone to emergency services
context: Keep sentences short and clear in emergencies—keywords matter more than grammar.
119 is Korea's emergency number (ambulance/fire). 112 is police.
At pharmacies or clinics, describing symptoms simply gets you quick aid.

sentences.english: Where is the hospital emergency room?
I have a bad headache. Do you have medicine?

sentences.korean: 저는 땅콩 알레르기가 있어요. 이 약 먹어도 돼요?
sentences.english: I have a peanut allergy. Can I take this medicine?
sentences.romanization: jeoneun ttangkong allereugi-ga isseoyo. i yak meogeodo dwaeyo?

explanation: Shout 도와주세요! or 경찰 불러 주세요! (Please call the police). Mention the issue fast: 사고 났어요 (There was an accident).
Emergency numbers: 119 for ambulance/fire, 112 for police. Say 위치 (location) + 상황 (situation).
At a pharmacy, say 증상이 뭐예요? (What are the symptoms?) or name them: 두통/복통/기침(=cough). Add 며칠째예요 (for how many days).
Use -아/어도 돼요? for permission: 이 약 먹어도 돼요? (Is it okay to take this?).
If you have allergies or conditions, say it first: 저는 ___ 알레르기가 있어요 / 저는 약에 알레르기 있어요.
